explanation:
For checking the MISRA rule on unreachable code you must inspect the bodies of every symbol directly invoked (and their direct callees) from send_bad_request because unreachable code anywhere in those implementations would violate the rule even if send_bad_request itself contains no dead code. Specifically:
- MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static: the target calls it; its implementation must be checked for unreachable branches or markers.
- MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback_cls: direct callee of the above; may contain unreachable code.
- MHD_queue_response: the target calls it; its implementation must be checked for unreachable branches or markers.
- MHD_DLOG, is_reply_body_needed, MHD_increment_response_rc, MHD_connection_handle_idle, MHD_update_last_activity_: direct callees of MHD_queue_response per the call graph; each may contain unreachable code and thus must be inspected.
- MHD_destroy_response: the target calls it; its implementation must be inspected (the call graph shows it invokes __builtin_unreachable).
- __builtin_unreachable: appears as a callee of MHD_destroy_response; occurrences of this builtin are direct indicators of unreachable code and must be reviewed in context.
- BAD_REQUEST_PAGE: the string/definition passed into the create_response call; include to ensure no macros/constructs hide unreachable code (and to understand the buffer argument usage).
- strlen: standard library call used in the same expression; include to confirm no macros/wrapper hide unreachable constructs.
- MHD_HTTP_BAD_REQUEST: constant passed to MHD_queue_response; include to ensure no macro expansion introduces unreachable constructs.

Inspecting these symbols (their definitions/implementations and any use of unreachable markers or unconditional returns) is sufficient to determine whether unreachable code exists in the parts of the project directly reachable from send_bad_request.
